description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, and language. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on Main Street), Jan Svêrák (Kolja), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Václav Havel, Ivan Klíma, and Arnost Lustig. Includes a comprehensive introduction to basic Czech for students with little or no knowledge of the language. The Czech language component is an integral cultural part of the course; all students must attend and participate in both morning and afternoon sessions. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information, e-mail summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.
title: Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. An intensive, hands-on exploration of film history, theory and practice, offered in partnership with FAMU, the national film academy of the Czech Republic. At the core of the workshop is a sequence of exercises and projects that recapitulates the evolution of film language, from its silent beginnings through its classical period to its post-modern present. Each exercise and project, guided by instructors from FAMU and Yale, and supported by topical lectures, screenings and workshops, will advance the student's understanding of film as art, craft and cultural institution. Cultural trips and activities include: a one-day orientation program comprising a welcome lunch, a walking tour of Prague, and an inaugural dinner; a 10-day introductory language course; a weekend trip to Uherské Hradiste for the opening weekend of the 37th annual Summer Film School, a unique film festival known throughout Europe for its energy and dynamism; and a celebratory farewell dinner. In the final week of the workshop, the student will draw on this understanding to produce a comprehensive final project. All instruction will be in English. Some previous film study is recommended, but not required. Enrollment limited to 16. Application deadline: February 1. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Yale Credit: Tuition: $3,000. 1 FAMU Credit: Tuition $3,000. Tuition is $6,000 total. Session B: July 2 - August 6.
title: The Yale Summer Film Institute at FAMU
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Paris, France. Introduction to French film history and culture focusing on the representation of Paris in film, photography and literature, with an emphasis on Paris as cultural capital of the cinema. Readings include essays on French film and culture, as well as novels and graphic novels by Aragon and Malet-Tardi. Visits to film locations and museums such as Le Forum Des Images, Le Centre Pompidou and La Cinematheque Francaise. Films include Les Vampires, Breathless, Les Amants de Pont-Neuf, La Haine, and Amelie. All readings and films in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 2 - August 6.
title: Paris and the Cinema
subject: FILM

description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory" - its past, its present, and its future - as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
short_title: The Hollywood Novel and the H...
title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. Exploration of animation (anime) and graphic novels (manga) in contemporary Japan. Special attention to the social and historical contexts of the production and consumption of manga and anime and to themes of gender and sexuality found within. Includes visits to animation and manga studios and museums, fan conventions, the Cosplay scene, and Kyoto. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.
title: Anime and Manga
subject: FILM

description: An intensive, comprehensive hands-on workshop in which the problems and aesthetics of filmmaking are studied in practice as well as theory. Students learn the narrative film form and its collaborative nature by participating in the production process. By screening classic narrative masterpieces they will gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic as well as develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with their fellow collaborators. The students will begin with seminars, readings and exercises that cover working with actors, script analysis, producing, camera, lighting, sound and editing and then move on to an actual production where as a group they make a short HD movie. Film professionals from various areas of expertise instruct and guide students in the application of industry standards to the exercises projects. The course is fully integrated with FILM S203 to provide filmmakers with a pool of acting talent and enable students to move beyond the technological requirements of the medium. This workshop requires a full daily commitment of the student's time, including 5 hours of classroom instruction, 2 hours of screenings, 1-2 hours of reading homework and workshop projects outside of class time and on weekends.  Enrollment limited to 16. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,800. More information on course web page: http://www.yale.edu/summer/progrms/film/filmmaking.html. . Course dates: June 13 - July 22.
title: Intensive Filmmaking Workshop
subject: FILM

description: An intensive, full-time, hands-on workshop that is fully integrated with the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop (Film S-202) which allows the student actor to solve the artistic problems and technical challenges of film acting. Students begin with exercises that acclimate them to the tenets of good acting under the pressures and demands of the filmic medium. Then, with rehearsed scene work, they learn the technical language of cinema and they participate in various filmmaking practices. Their knowledge and techniques are tested by acting in one or more of the films produced by the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop. With the Filmmaking Workshop, the students screen classic narrative masterpieces nightly in order to gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic context as well as to develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with fellow collaborators. Screenings, readings, and rehearsals supplement practical application. Daily commitments include, but are not limited to: 3-5 hours daily of classroom instruction, 2.5 hours of nightly screenings, 1-3 hours daily reading, rehearsal and shooting sessions outside of classroom time and on weekends. Enrollment limited to 16. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. More information on course web page: http://www.yale.edu/summer/progrms/film/acting.html. Dates: June 13 - July 22, M-Th  9.30-12.30; M, W 2-4; Screenings M-Th 7-10 P.M.
title: Acting in Film
subject: FILM

description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Money and Media: the Business of Hollywood
subject: FILM

description: Shakespeare's plays examined in and through film. Ways in which the processes of film adaptation and production have reshaped the form and meaning of Shakespeare's works. Emphasis on the specifics of cinematic form and style in relation to the theatrical conditions for which the plays were originally written. Analysis of films from different historical periods, cultural contexts, and genres. Some discussion of relevant historical and theoretical developments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Shakespeare on Film
subject: FILM

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment.  This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture and society.  In-class screenings will include The Birth of a Nation, Scarface, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: FILM

description: A seminar and workshop in screenplay writing. Students learn the basics of the craft by reading existing scripts, looking at films from a writer's perspective, and writing a short screenplay. Additional hours of individual screenings required. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Screenwriting
subject: FILM

description: The outlaw as a romanticized, mythic figure in Anglo-American film and culture. Analysis of movies and screenplays whose characters refuse to conform to a restrictive social order in which they have a marginal place. Evolving depictions of the outlaw in mainstream cinema after World War II.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 5 - August 6.
title: Outlaw Cinema
subject: FILM

description: Examines crime drama (with a concentration on HBO's "THE WIRE"), crime news, reality TV, and crime documentaries. Analysis of how depictions in these media effect law enforcement, government, politics, labor, community, education, criminality/violence, progressive and conservative pundits, judicial responsibility and social perceptions of race, class, gender, and sexuality. 60 Minutes correspondent Leslie Stahl, a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, will visit and discuss the history of sexism in broadcasting; her interviews with Mark Zuckerberg & Supreme Court Justice Scalia; her investigations into social media crime; and the controversy surrounding familial searches of DNA databases. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Television and Crime
subject: FILM

description: An introductory analysis of the television situation comedy in America from its beginnings in the 1950s to the present time. Exploration of how this popular and powerful genre grew and changed, how it influenced America, and how it was influenced by America in its depictions of family life, race and ethnicity, stereotypes, fantasy, feminism, war, progressive forms of cultural and racial inclusion, and contemporary looks at single life and gay liberation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Television Situation Comedy
subject: FILM

description: Intensive training and practice in all the language skills through extensive use of audio and video material, with an initial emphasis on listening and speaking. Authentic, unsimplified French is used as in actual situations. Emphasis on communicative proficiency, the development of skills, self-expression, and cultural insights. Classes are supplemented by regular laboratory assignments. Conducted entirely in French. Daily classroom and laboratory attendance is required. For students with no previous study of French. 1 1/2 credits. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S120 in the same summer for credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Elementary and Intermediate French
subject: FREN

description: Continuation of FREN S110. 1 1/2 Credits. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S110 in the same summer for credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Elementary and Intermediate French
subject: FREN

description: Part 1 of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Conducted entirely in French. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: June 6 - July 30.
title: Intermediate and Advanced French I
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Part 2 of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Conducted entirely in French. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S130. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent.  Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,000. Course dates: June 6 - July 30.
title: Intermediate and Advanced French II
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. An advanced language course intended to improve students' comprehension of spoken and written French as well as their speaking and writing skills. Museum visits, theater outings, and weekend trips complement the reading of modern fiction and nonfiction texts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 140, 145, or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 28 - July 2.
title: Advanced Language Practice II
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings; discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals; films; songs; stories; and clips from French television. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 150, 151, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 28 - July 2.
title: Advanced Culture and Conversation
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. Study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France. Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual life in twelfth- and thirteenth-century Paris. Discussion of historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, and Thibaut de Champagne. Visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens and Cluny Museum. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in France between the Franco-Prussian War and World War I. Includes visits to museums, monuments, art nouveau cafés, bistrots, brasseries, and other sites in Paris. Readings, writing, and discussion in French. Prerequisite: two courses in the FREN 150-159 range or the equivalent. Recommended preparation: a course in the FREN 170-175 range. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session A: May 28 - July 2.
title: Belle Epoque France
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. An introduction to French literature and arts after World War II. Topics include existentialism, intellectual and artistic life of Paris in the 1950s, the theater of the absurd, cinema d'auteur, and the contemporary French novel. Exploration of Parisian cultural life through visits to literary cafes, the National Library, the Cinematheque, theaters, and bookstores. Readings, writing, and discussion in French. Prerequisite: two courses in the FREN 150-159 range or the equivalent. Recommended preparation: a course in the FREN 170-175 range. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 2 - August 6
title: French Literature and Arts after 1945
subject: FREN

description: Part 1 of an intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Application deadline: February 1 . Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.
title: Intermediate German I
subject: GMAN

description: Offered in Berlin, Germany. Part 2 of an intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S130. Prerequisite: GMAN 130 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.
title: Intermediate German II
subject: GMAN

description: Offered in Berlin, Germany. An advanced language course focused on improving upper-level language skills through exploration of the culture, politics, art, and history of twentieth-century Berlin. Dicussion of current events; site visits in Berlin; interviews with host families. Topics include history and memory, art and music, architecture and living conditions, youth and alternative cultures, and national and international politics. Prerequisite: GMAN 140a or b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, room and board costs in Germany , and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Course dates: June 25-July 30. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000.
title: Metropolis Berlin
subject: GMAN

description: Introduction to ancient Greek. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for GREK S120. No prior knowledge of Greek assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Beginning Greek: The Elements of Grammar
subject: GREK

description: Continuation of GREK S110.  Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Greek authors. The sequence GREK S110, S120 prepares for GREK 131 or 141.  Prerequisite: GREK S110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Beginning Greek: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
subject: GREK

description: The relationship between religion and war in American history from colonial beginnings through Vietnam. The religious meaning of America, including the religious meanings of Americans at war; the mutually reinforcing influences of nationalism and religion; war as the norm of American national life; the concept of civil religion; biblical and messianic contexts of key U.S. conflicts. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Religion, War, and America
subject: HIST

description: The history of westward expansion and of the places west of the Mississippi River, as told through the people who saw it, experienced it, and made it happen.  Beginning in the colonial era and concluding in the present day, with an emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.  Research will include the use of Overland Diaries from the Beinecke.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
short_title: The History of the American West
title: The History of the American West
subject: HIST

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment.  This course seeks to expand its students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture and society.  In-class screenings will include The Birth of a Nation, Scarface, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: HIST

description: The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the mechanically reproduced book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mass literacy and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar at the Beinecke Rare Book Library through a series of first-hand encounters with rare manuscripts, books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
subject: HIST

description: Explores encounters between Russia and the West from the eighteenth century to the present.  How has Russia reacted to major events and ideas in the West, and vice-versa?  Examines selected major political events and intellectual controversies, as well cross-cultural exchange. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Russia and the West
subject: HIST

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4-August 5.
title: The Cold War
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study of southeastern Europe from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and postcommunist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session B: July 2 - August 6.
title: History and Culture of Southeastern Europe
subject: HIST

description: Survey of the history of China, Japan, and Korea from the seventh century to the present. Focus on three separate empires: the Tang, Manchu, and Japanese. Attention to interactions among East Asian regions in the past and today. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Empires of East Asia
subject: HIST

description: Major conflicts, revolutions, and wars in the Persian Gulf during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Topics include conflicts between the Ottoman Empire, Iran, and Arab Gulf areas; Arab-Iranian rivalry; the role of Islam in state and society; tribal communities within states; British occupations; the emergence of Kuwait, Iraq, and modern Iran; revolutions in Iraq and Iran; and the twentieth-century Gulf Wars. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
short_title: Iran, Iraq, and the Persian Gulf
title: Iran, Iraq, and the Persian Gulf
subject: HIST

description: A survey of the interaction of political, economic, and environmental factors in the history of the Eurasian steppe from antiquity to the modern era, and the interactions of its peoples with civilizations in China, India, Persia, Russia, and Europe. Topics include Scythians, Huns, Mongols, Silk Road trade, expansion of the Russian and Chinese empires into the steppe and the consequent destruction of political structures and economic productivity, Afghanistan as a juncture point, post-Soviet petrostates. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Central Asia and Empire
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Survey of the modern history of East Africa, with a focus on health, environment, and society. The rise of Swahili language and culture; slavery and plantation agriculture; colonial regimes, medical discourse, and environmental degradation; agrarian protest and nationalist mobilization; conservation ethics and national parks; female genital cutting; HIV/AIDS. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, costs of room and board in Mombasa, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Yale students may petition for one HU area credit. Tuition: $5,800. Course Dates: June 25 - August 6.
title: History of East Africa
subject: HIST

description: The emergence of internationalism during the final years of World War I and its immediate aftermath, and the descent toward obsolescence of the empire model in world politics. Responses to Woodrow Wilson's peace diplomacy and the League of Nations; the Russian revolution and the subsequent upheaval across Eurasia; the struggles for Indian, Irish, and Czech independence; the birth of modern nationalism in Asia. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: World Politics 1917-1919
subject: HIST

description: A history of artistic expression from prehistory to the Renaissance. Selected studies of architecture, sculpture, painting, metalwork, manuscript illumination, etc. Lectures in the classroom and gallery talks in the Yale University Art Gallery, Beinecke Library, and The Cloisters Museum in New York. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to History of Art: Prehistory to the Renaissance
subject: HSAR

description: A survey of Western art from the fifteenth century to the present. Introduction to both the masterpieces of artistic expression and the methods for defining and interpreting those works. Field trips to Yale museums and architectural walking tours complement the study of paintings, sculptures, architecture, and domestic and luxury arts. Readings include survey texts and original sources. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to History of Art: Renaissance to Modern
subject: HSAR

description: Chronological and thematic issues related to the creation, analysis, and collecting of African American art. Introduction to the field of African American art through close engagement with archival sources and art objects held in the Yale University Art Gallery and the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library. Methodologies used to write about art in both African American studies and art history; collecting and museum practices; the relationships between art, artists, and community formations. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: African American Art at Yale
subject: HSAR

description: The historical relationship between art and science in the West, from the Renaissance to the present. Case studies illustrate the similarities and differences between the way artists and scientists each model the world, in the studio and the laboratory. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Art and Science
subject: HSAR

description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Ten Works of Western Art
subject: HSAR

description: This course explores the ways in which theater based processes have been used to facilitate learning, promote wellness, and address a variety of social concerns such as access to education and healthcare, poverty, gender-based violence, racism, and displacement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

subject: HUMS

description: The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart and Friends
subject: HUMS

description: May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 130 (Intermediate Italian I) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.
title: Intermediate Italian II
subject: ITAL

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Second part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. Students complete the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the three weeks on the Yale campus, followed by the equivalent of one term of intermediate Italian during the five weeks in Italy. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 130 (Intermediate Italian I) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.
title: Intermediate Italian II
subject: ITAL

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Close reading of selected texts written by the three cornerstones of Italian literary history: Dante, Petrarch, and Boccaccio. Texts are situated within the specific, concrete topography of Tuscany. The making of Tuscany as a political, moral, and aesthetic myth in the Middle Ages; emergence of the Tuscan language as the standard language of Italy. Readings and discussion in Italian. Prerequisite: ITAL 140b or equivalent. May not be taken for credit after ITAL 334b. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Course dates: June 18 - July 23.
title: The Three Crowns of Tuscany
subject: ITAL

description: Introduction to historical developments and fundamental political issues in Latin America. Overview of socioeconomic and political development since the discovery of the Americas, with a focus on key contemporary debates. Emphasis on the unique and innovative ways in which Latin American societies approach socioeconomic, political, and cultural conflicts such as military-civilian relationships, internal armed conflict, socioeconomic inequality, and respect for human rights. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Latin American Politics
subject: LAST

description: Introduction to Latin. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for LATN 120.  No prior knowledge of Latin assumed. Primarily for graduate students. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Beginning Latin: The Elements of Grammar
subject: LATN

description: Continuation of LATN 110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Latin authors. The sequence LATN 110, 120 prepares for 131 or 141. Prerequisite: LATN 110 or equivalent. Primarily for graduate students. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
subject: LATN

description: Study of medieval Latin's distinctive style and vocabulary. Survey of major historical and literary works of the European Middle Ages. Use of medieval manuscript resources from the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, with an introduction to basics of paleography and codicology. Prerequisites: LATN 141b or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Medieval Latin
subject: LATN

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Study of the linguistic landscape of India, focusing particularly on the Indo-Aryan and Dravidian linguistic areas. The historical evolution of the multilingual landscape over time, and its political and social implications in contemporary India. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S305/ANTH S305. Students are responsible for all travels expenses to and from India, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session A: May 28 - July 2.
title: A Linguistic History of India
subject: LING

description: Examination of how stories are told in both literary and nonliterary texts, with special attention to the act of decoding and interpreting a narrative. Emphasis on fictional form, the mechanics of plot, and questions of time and character. Topics include confession, memory, language, the representation of the self, the interplay of form and content, and the relationship between fiction and history. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Narrative
subject: LITR

description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Classical Mythologies
subject: LITR

description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. Study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France. Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual life in twelfth- and thirteenth-century Paris. Discussion of historical and literary works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, and Thibaut de Champagne. Visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens and Cluny Museum. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: LITR

description: Exploration of various theoretical and practical problems in translation. Topics include the responsibility of the translator to the text, the author and the reader; the reliability of translation as a literary mode; the transmission or perversion of culture via translation; and the specific problems involved with the translation of various genres (poetry, drama, fiction, non-fiction). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Translation: Literature and Practice
subject: LITR

description: Offered in Paris, France. The role of Paris in the works of writers such as Joyce, Hemingway, Colette, and Breton. How the situation of the artist as expatriate or exile affects what can be written. Iconoclasts of experimental language who found a congenial home in Paris, including Gertrude Stein and the surrealists. Works of expatriate British and American writers examined in relation to works by contemporary French authors. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 28 - July 2.
title: Paris in the 20's
subject: LITR

description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should enroll in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
subject: MATH

description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should enroll in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
subject: MATH

description: The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
subject: MATH

description: (Formerly "Mathematics for Economists".) Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
subject: MATH

description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. Prerequisite: two terms of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 and 115 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
subject: MATH

description: Introduction to biochemistry, genetics, cell biology, and early development. Emphasis on the cell as the basic unit of life; the cell's composition, functions, replication, and differentiation. This course, with laboratory, meets departmental requirements for the major, and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Students should take this course with the laboratory, MCDB S121, which together constitute a full course load. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Principles of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology
subject: MCDB

description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. Must be taken concurrently with or after MCDB 120. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology
subject: MCDB

description: For non-science majors. The biology of the brain as it relates to various functions and dysfunctions. Gross anatomy and cellular composition of nervous system tissue; development of the nervous system, including its organization into motor, sensory, and other systems; the biology underlying complex processes such as learning, memory, and mood regulation; psychoactive and performance-enhancing drugs in the brain; disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, autism, and depression. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: How the Brain Works
subject: MCDB

description: A comprehensive course in cell and molecular biology.  Emphasis on general principles of cell function and rationale and design of pertinent biomedical experiments. Prerequisite: MCDB 120. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Cell Biology
subject: MCDB

description: The historical development of the global Muslim community, from its origins in seventh-century Arabia through its spread over subsequent centuries into the Middle East, Africa, Central and South/Southeast Asia, and the West. The tremendous variation and complexity expressed in society, culture, and politics across the Islamic world; Islam as a unifying factor on critical issues such as religious practice, political structure and activism, gender, and cultural expression. 1 Credit. Tuition: $,3000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Islamic Society, Culture, and Politics
subject: MMES

description: Offered online. An overview of politics in the Middle East and North Africa. State formation, the roles of religion and oil in politics, political institutions, economic development, and the prospects for economic and political reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Middle East Politics
subject: MMES

description: The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart and Friends
subject: MUSI

description: This section offered online.The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart and Friends
subject: MUSI

description: A study of the evolution of jazz, from its precursors in the music of Africa through its beginnings in New Orleans to its fusion with rock in the 1970s . Jazz's greatest artists and their styles are presented with selected music of each jazz period and a discussion of the racial and sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Jazz and Race in America
subject: MUSI

description:
Offered at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, TN. Program dates: June 20  July 29, 2011. An intensive immersion course designed to familiarize students with modern and colonial Nahuatl. Beginning, intermediate and advanced level students may apply. Formal class hours are complemented with individual language practice sessions and group cultural activities. 3 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Partial scholarships are available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Nashville. Housing in Vanderbilt University dormitories is available, for students wishing to stay on campus, at a cost of $945 per student for 42 nights, with two students per room. Students are free to make off-campus housing arrangements on their own. Meal Plan: Students may sign up for a meal plan that covers breakfast and lunch during the week at $15.68 per day or $470.40 for the 30 week days of the program; students will be responsible for dinners and weekend meals. The meal plan is optional. For questions regarding housing and meal plan, contact: Norma Antillón: norma.g.antillon@vanderbilt.edu or 615-322-2527. Details on the Yale Latin American and Iberian Studies website, http://www.yale.edu/macmillan/lais/summer.html
Or contact Jean Silk, jean.silk@yale.edu for further information.
title: Intensive Nahuatl Language and Culture
subject: NHTL

description: 3 credit hours. Community health nurses provide preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitation, and hospice services across the life span. The clinical experience focuses on the delivery of these health services in domestic community organizations. Nursing responsibility for caseload management offers an opportunity to interact with other members of the interdisciplinary health care team. A community-as-partner assessment and diagnosis project, which culminates in identification of a community health problem and potential solutions, augments core clinical practice. At the beginning of the following fall term, all students are required to present their community projects at a poster session. In addition, students at remote sites meet with the course coordinator at a time to be announced in the fall of the following term. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required for all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Clinical Practice in Community Health Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. Sessions explore the multidisciplinary theoretical foundations that are the basis for community health nursing practice across the life span. Topics include history of community health nursing and public health science; structure and function of federal, state, and local health organizations; funding mechanisms for community health care; epidemiological and biostatistical indicators of community health; methods of family and community analyses. Required for all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Seminar in Community Health Nursing and Public Health
subject: NURS

title: Clincial Prac. Adult Psych-MH
subject: NURS

description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.
title: Master's Independent Study
subject: NURS

subject: NURS

description: 4.3 credit hours. The focus of this practicum is comprehensive management of a caseload of patients with students' elected special populations (cardiovascular, oncology). Emphasis is on prediction of common patient problems, formulation of management protocols, and generation of research questions. The practice sites in acute, ambulatory, and/or long-term settings provide an opportunity to observe system problems and develop clinical leadership strategies. Required for clinical nurse specialist students in the final year of specialization. Acute care nurse practitioner students must take 810c during the summer following 612b, unless they can demonstrate experience in caring for critically ill patients managed with complex technological interventions. Twelve hours of clinical practice plus one hour of clinical conference per week.
title: Advanced Specialty Practicum II
subject: NURS

description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. How new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea. Whether happiness should be a goal in life. The relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Happiness
subject: PHIL

description: An introduction to the philosophy of religion, focusing on the problem of evil: if there is an all-powerful and morally good God, then why is there so much evil in the world? Examination of attempts to reconcile the existence of God with evil by appealing to human free will. Such attempts raise other important philosophical questions: what is free will, and is it compatible with the laws of physics, or with divine providence? Why is freedom valuable? 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Free Will, Good, and Evil
subject: PHIL

description: An introduction to formal logic. Study of the formal deductive systems and semantics for both propositional and predicate logic. Some discussion of metatheory. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: First-Order Logic
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to the field of ethics. Topics include the basis of morality, what a person is morally required to do for others, and what makes one act right and another wrong. Attention to theories associated with John Stuart Mill, Immanuel Kant, and Aristotle. Some consideration of how ethical theory can be applied to particular questions in society and in our personal lives. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Ethics
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Eastern Philosophy
subject: PHIL

description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: PHYS

description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: PHYS

description: First part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles, with examples of practical applications to medicine and other fields. Covers mechanics, thermodynamics, and wave motion. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. PHYS 150 and 151 are normally taken in sequence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: General Physics
subject: PHYS

description: Second part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics.  Emphasis on fundamental principles, with examples of practical applications to medicine and other fields. Covers electricity and magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. Prerequisite: PHYS 150 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: General Physics
subject: PHYS

description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S170, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. Pre-college students with a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: General Physics Laboratory
subject: PHYS

description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S171, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. Pre-college students with a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. 1/2 Credit. Tuition: $1,500. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: General Physics Laboratory
subject: PHYS

description: First part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles and on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Covers vectors, kinematics, Newton's laws of motion, oscillations and waves, gravitation, elasticity, statics, diffusion, fluids, and thermodynamics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. PHYS 170 and 171 are normally taken in sequence. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: University Physics for the Life Sciences
subject: PHYS

description: Second part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles and on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Covers electricity and magnetism, circuits, light and optics, sound, and modern physics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre-college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. Prerequisite: PHYS 170 or equivalent.  1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: University Physics for Life Sciences
subject: PHYS

description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, waves, and thermodynamics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 170, 171. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: University Physics
subject: PHYS

description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers electromagnetism, optics, special relativity, and quantum physics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 170, 171. Prerequisite: PHYS 180 or equivalent. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: University Physics
subject: PHYS

description: A study of contemporary political issues that are international in scope: war, globalization, terrorism, human rights, immigration, development, and the environment. Topics include relations between states, international organizations such as the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, and the World Bank, and nongovernmental bodies, including multinational corporations, nonprofit organizations, and armed groups. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to International Relations
subject: PLSC

description: Issues of liberty, equality, and justice considered from within the Western tradition of political philosophy. Readings from Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Political Philosophy
subject: PLSC

description: Exploration of how violence and religion intersect historically, sociologically, and analytically. Comparative examination of religion and conflict over time and space. Focus on the major monotheistic religions, with some attention to classical polytheistic societies. Definitions of religious violence; whether religious violence is a different topic from religion and violence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Religion and Violence
subject: PLSC

description: Investigation of the role played by international factors such as socialization, coercion, and emulation in the current wave of democratizations around the world. Focus on the extent to which democratic processes can  be affected from the outside. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B July 4 - August 5
title: International Dimensions of Democratization
subject: PLSC

description: Offered in Mexico City, Mexico. International human rights bodies and their implications for international politics. The role of human rights institutions in affording remedies to victims of state abuse. The emergence and exercise of international human rights law, including its nature, mechanisms, and logic. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mexico, costs of room and board while in Mexico, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: International Human Rights and Politics
subject: PLSC

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4-August 5.
title: The Cold War
subject: PLSC

description: Ways in which institutions affect the functioning of democracy in the United States. Focus on representation of citizens' preferences in the public sphere. Institutions studied include primary elections, redistricting, campaign finance, early voting, multimember districts, pivotal politics, legislative committees, term limits, and term lengths. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Institutions and Representation in American Democracy
subject: PLSC

description: The news media's role in configuring the democratic public sphere, from the early synergy of print capitalism and liberalism through the corporate consolidation of mass media and the recent fragmentation and fluidity of "news." Classical-humanist and civic-republican responses to these trends. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Journalism, Liberalism, and Democracy
subject: PLSC

description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Focus on various theories of criminal process in light of empirical evidence, the politicization of crime, civil rights issues, psychiatry and the law, abortion, and arguments about prison reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Crime and Punishment
subject: PLSC

description: A survey of the historical development of the executive branch of the American national government; an examination of the politics of presidential leadership; and consideration of how the development of the executive branch has affected presidential politics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: The American Presidency
subject: PLSC

description: Survey of major themes and concepts in Islamic political thought. Events and dynasties of the formative period. The building blocks of orthodox Islamic political thought, situated within the tradition of Islamic law. Examination of contemporary trends. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Islamic Political Thought
subject: PLSC

description: An overview of politics in the Middle East and North Africa. State formation, the roles of religion and oil in politics, political institutions, economic development, and the prospects for economic and political reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Middle East Politics
subject: PLSC

description: Offered online. An overview of politics in the Middle East and North Africa. State formation, the roles of religion and oil in politics, political institutions, economic development, and the prospects for economic and political reform. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Middle East Politics
subject: PLSC

description: Study of contemporary work on ethnicity and nationalism from multiple disciplines and analytic traditions. Factors that make ethnicity and nationalism distinctive among social bases of political mobilization. Critical examination of the theory that nationalism is an exclusively modern phenomenon. Nationalism as an attempt to tie powerful organizations to specific territories and individual loyalties. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: The Politics of Nationalism and Ethnicity
subject: PLSC

description: Introduction to historical developments and fundamental political issues in Latin America. Overview of socioeconomic and political development since the discovery of the Americas, with a focus on key contemporary debates. Emphasis on the unique and innovative ways in which Latin American societies approach socioeconomic, political, and cultural conflicts such as military-civilian relationships, internal armed conflict, socioeconomic inequality, and respect for human rights. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Latin American Politics
subject: PLSC

description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in conjunction with PORT S122. A comprehensive Portuguese course for students proficient in Spanish or another Romance language. Basic vocabulary and fundamentals of grammar through practice in speaking, reading, and writing; conversational practice. Conducted entirely in Portuguese. Normally prepares for PORT 130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S352. Note that the course meets M-F, 9am-12pm in New Haven and M-F, 1pm-4pm in Paraty. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150.  Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.
title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages
subject: PORT

description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in conjunction with PORT S112. A comprehensive Portuguese course for students proficient in Spanish or another Romance language. Basic vocabulary and fundamentals of grammar through practice in speaking, reading, and writing; conversational practice. Conducted entirely in Portuguese. Normally prepares for PORT 130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S352. Note that the course meets M-F, 9am-12pm in New Haven and M-F, 1pm-4pm in Paraty. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150.  Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.
title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages
subject: PORT

description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in conjunction with PORT S140. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. An introduction to Brazilian cultural topics reflects the history and geography of the area. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S352. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150.  Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.
title: Intermediate Portuguese
subject: PORT

description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in conjunction with PORT S130. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. An introduction to Brazilian cultural topics reflects the history and geography of the area. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S352. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150.  Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.
title: Intermediate Portuguese
subject: PORT

description: Two weeks offered in New Haven, six weeks offered in Paraty and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. A comprehensive introduction to Brazilian cultural history, including formation, chronological development, and modern self-description. Cultural perspectives underlying current issues such as immigration, modernization, urbanization, race and ethnicity, the arts, literature, and national identity. Texts by major authors and figures in Brazilian literary, cultural, and intellectual history. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rio de Janiero, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112/S122 or PORT S130/S140. Note that the course meets MW, 1pm-3pm in New Haven and MW, 4:30pm-6:30pm in Paraty. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: See PORT S112/S122 or PORT S130/S140 for tuition. Course Dates: June 6 - July 30.
title: Introduction to Brazil
subject: PORT

description: A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Psychology
subject: PSYC

description: Multidisciplinary approach to studying the nature of the mind. How the fields of philosophy, psychology, neuroscience, computer science, and linguistics contribute methods, theories, and research to addressing questions about how the mind works. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Cognitive Science
subject: PSYC

description: Introduction to research and theory on the development and changes in perception, cognition, emotion and social functioning across the life span. Focus on birth through adulthood. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Developmental Psychology
subject: PSYC

description: How natural selection works and how it can be applied to the study of human psychology. Attention to research methods and findings. Topics include sex and mating, alliances, kinship, visual attention, spatial cognition and memory, and social exchange. May not be taken for credit after PSYC S171b. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Evolution and Cognition
subject: PSYC

description: Study of the major forms of psychopathology that appear in childhood and adult life. Topics include the symptoms of mental disorders; the etiology of disorders from a variety of perspectives (psychological, biological, and sociocultural); and issues pertaining to diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1..
title: Abnormal Psychology
subject: PSYC
