description: Study of ancient Jewish, Christian, and Muslim interpretations of Genesis 1-3. Stories of creation and the "fall" of Adam as creatively reread in the biblical psalms, rabbinic midrash, New Testament writings, gnostic myth, the Qur'an, and early Islamic commentary. The influence of such interpretations on views of God, politics, society, and the human body. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Jews, Christians, and Muslims on Genesis and Gender
subject: RLST

description: Introduction to Islam. Arabia and the rise of Islam. Muhammad and the Qur'an. Muslim traditions and religious law. Basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community. Islamic philosophy and theology. Shi'ism and Sufism. Religious institutions and modern trends. Jihad and fundamentalism. Religious freedom and democracy in Islam. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Religion of Islam
subject: RLST

description: An inquiry into the possibility, nature, and purpose of Christian ethics through examination of principal positions developed in the Western church. The relationship of religion to ethics; sources of moral authority; the goals that constitute the good life. Authors include Adams, Augustine, Barth, Butler, Calvin, Gustafson, Kant, Kierkegaard, Luther, Plato, Thomas, and Yoder. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Christian Ethics
subject: RLST

description: The relationship between religion and war in American history from colonial beginnings through Vietnam. The religious meaning of America, including the religious meanings of Americans at war; the mutually reinforcing influences of nationalism and religion; war as the norm of American national life; the concept of civil religion; biblical and messianic contexts of key U.S. conflicts. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Religion, War, and America
subject: RLST

description: From the garreting of Harriet Jacobs to Tyler Perry as Madea, this course introduces students to applied religious ethics through an exploration of black faith and sexuality in the United States. Students will learn basic foundational models for understanding religious ethics in philosophical, theological, and social terms while engaging the intersections of race, gender, sexuality, and faith. This course explores ethical frameworks functioning within cultural theory, historical accounts, film, and works of fiction. Students will be guided in a consideration of the roles of creativity and imagination in the formations of race, faith, and sexuality. Topics include sexual violence and exploitation, respectability and the black family, reclaiming the erotic, and new spiritualities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Black Faith and Sexuality
subject: RLST

description: First part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the first three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the last five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S140 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: May 30 - July 25.
title: Second-Year Russian
subject: RUSS

description: Second part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the first three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the last five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S130 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: May 30 - July 25.
title: Second-Year Russian
subject: RUSS

description: Second half offered in St. Petersburg, Russia. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third-year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the first three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the last five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S151 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,150. Course dates: May 30 - July 25.
title: Third-Year Russian
subject: RUSS

description: Secon part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third-year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the first three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the last five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S150 & RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Course dates: May 30 - July 25.
title: Third-Year Russian
subject: RUSS

description: Second half offered in St. Petersburg, Russia. An interdisciplinary exploration of Russian cultural history through its art, architecture, theater, music, and film. Topics include conceptions of Russian nationhood; myths of St. Petersburg and Moscow; dissent and persecution; elites, intelligentsia, and attitudes toward the common people; conflicting appeals of rationality, spirituality, and idealism; the politicizing of personal life; and effects of Russian artistic innovations worldwide. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS 130/140 or RUSS S150/151. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S130/140 or RUSS S 150/151.  Course Dates: May 30 - July 25.
title: Russian Culture
subject: RUSS

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Critical introduction to contemporary Indian politics, society, culture, and religion through immersive study in Mumbai. Topics include urbanization, poverty, migration, housing, communal violence, caste segregation, class ghettoization, and popular culture. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S364/LING S119. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session A: May 28- July 2.
title: Bombay: City, Society and Culture
subject: SAST

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Study of the linguistic landscape of India, focusing particularly on the Indo-Aryan and Dravidian linguistic areas. The historical evolution of the multilingual landscape over time, and its political and social implications in contemporary India. Must be taken in conjunction with SAST S305/ANTH S305. Students are responsible for all travels expenses to and from India, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For more information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session A: May 28 - July 2.
title: A Linguistic History of India
subject: SAST

description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design and data interpretation, through lectures, reading and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions of preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative informations. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition: $3,ooo. June 6 - August 5.
title: Scientific Research: Process and Presentation
subject: SCIE

description: The historical development of the global Muslim community, from its origins in seventh-century Arabia through its spread over subsequent centuries into the Middle East, Africa, Central and South/Southeast Asia, and the West. The tremendous variation and complexity expressed in society, culture, and politics across the Islamic world; Islam as a unifying factor on critical issues such as religious practice, political structure and activism, gender, and cultural expression. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Islamic Society, Culture, and Politics
subject: SOCY

description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology. Attention to social and historical contexts, conceptual frameworks and methods, and contributions to contemporary social analysis. Writers include Hobbes, Locke, J.S. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Foundations of Modern Social Theory
subject: SOCY

description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation states. Mechanisms and challenges involved in incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Global Public Health
subject: SOCY

description: Introduction to the sociological study of collective political protest. Different approaches to analyzing and making sense of such social movements, including their historical emergence as a modern form of public politics. How and why social movements develop, mobilize collective action, and decline. Case studies from the United States, China, and recent events in North Africa and the Middle East. Recommended preparation: an introductory course in sociology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Social Movements
subject: SOCY

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories and debates.  Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: SOCY

description: Work is one of the defining experiences of modern social life, but what is it? Things like the structure of the labor market, professions, careers, and job status play major roles in our contemporary social lives, but why do these things take their current form? And where is work heading in the future? Using various sociological concepts and empirical studies, the course introduces students to these and other questions that define the meaning of work in contemporary social life. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 -July 1.
title: Sociology of Work
subject: SOCY

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study of southeastern Europe from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and postcommunist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 credit. Tuition: $2,900. Session B: July 2 - August 6.
title: Culture of Southeastern Europe
subject: SOCY

description: For students who wish to begin study of the Spanish language. Development of basic skills in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing through a functional approach to the teaching of spanish grammar. Includes an introduction to the cultures (traditions, art, literature, music) of the Spanish-speaking world. Audio-visual materials are incorporated into class sessions. Conducted in Spanish. To be followed by SPAN S120.  Credit only on completion of SPAN S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Elementary Spanish I
subject: SPAN

Cultural topics of the Spanish-speaking world (traditions, art, literature, music) are included. Conducted in Spanish. After SPAN S110 or in accordance with placement results. Admits to SPAN 130 or 145. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.

subject: SPAN

description: First part of an intensive "at home and abroad" course, designed to develop students' proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, Spain (CRN 30239) or Quito, Ecuador (CRN 30243), costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 (in Bilbao, CRN 30240) or SPAN S140 (in Quito, CRN 30244) and S248 (Spain, 1936 to the Present) or S249 (Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to the Present). Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,150. Bilbao course dates: May 30  July 26. Quito course dates: May 30 - July 23.
title: Intermediate Spanish I
subject: SPAN

description: Last four weeks offered in Bilbao, Spain. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/140. Course dates: May 30 - July 26.
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
subject: SPAN

description: Last four weeks offered in Quito, Ecuador. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Ecuador from Pre-Columbian times to the present. Presented through a variety of materials (literary texts, essays, films, music, visual arts). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: May 30 - July 23.
title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to Present
subject: SPAN

description: An examination of forces shaping American cities and strategies for dealing with them. Topics include housing, commercial development, parks, zoning, urban renewal, landmark preservation, new towns, and suburbs. Includes games, simulated problems, fieldwork, lectures, and discussion as well as field trips in New Haven and to New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to the Study of the City
subject: STCY

description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Further development of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Prerequisite: SWAH 120b (Elementary Kiswahili II) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu.  Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $2,500. Course dates: May 28 -July 23.

subject: SWAH

Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu.  Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $2,500. Course Dates: May 28 - July 23.
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
subject: SWAH

description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Kenya, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. For further information contact summersession.abroad@yale.edu. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,000. Course dates: May 28 - July 9.
title: Advanced Kiswahili
subject: SWAH

description: This course explores the ways in which theater based processes have been used to facilitate learning, promote wellness, and address a variety of social concerns such as access to education and healthcare, poverty, gender-based violence, racism, and displacement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Applied Theater, Trauma, Cultural Intervention
subject: THST

description: In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Modern American Drama
subject: THST

description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to Peabody Museum, Beinecke Library, Yale Farm and Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Women, Food and Culture
subject: WGSS

description: Introduction to scholarship on the anthropology of reproduction. Focus on reproductive technologies such as contraceptives, prenatal diagnostics, childbirth technologies, abortion, assisted reproduction, and reproductive technologies that engender harm, such as sex selection and female circumcision. The globalization of reproductive technologies, including social, cultural, legal, and ethical responses. Recommended preparation: ANTH 110b or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Reproductive Technologies
subject: WGSS

description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. Exploration of animation (anime) and graphic novels (manga) in contemporary Japan. Special attention to the social and historical contexts of the production and consumption of manga and anime and to themes of gender and sexuality found within. Includes visits to animation and manga studios and museums, fan conventions, the Cosplay scene, and Kyoto. 2 Credits. Tuition: $5,800. Session B: July 2 - August 6.
title: Anime and Manga
subject: WGSS

description: Cultural and historic constructions of masculinity explored through an investigation of male bodies, sexualities, and social interactions. Multiple masculinities; the relationship between hegemonic, nonhegemonic, and subordinate masculinities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Men, Manhood, and Masculinity
subject: WGSS

description: From the garreting of Harriet Jacobs to Tyler Perry as Madea, this course introduces students to applied religious ethics through an exploration of black faith and sexuality in the United States. Students will learn basic foundational models for understanding religious ethics in philosophical, theological, and social terms while engaging the intersections of race, gender, sexuality, and faith. This course explores ethical frameworks functioning within cultural theory, historical accounts, film, and works of fiction. Students will be guided in a consideration of the roles of creativity and imagination in the formations of race, faith, and sexuality. Topics include sexual violence and exploitation, respectability and the black family, reclaiming the erotic, and new spiritualities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Black Faith and Sexuality
subject: WGSS

description: Theoretical, methodological, and aesthetic models in the field of critical ethnography, which seeks to understand and illustrate lived experiences of subjects who are differently situated in social webs of power. Models drawn mostly from race theory, postcolonial theory, queer theory, and feminisms. Problems of methodology, ethics, politics, and poetics that have an impact on students' own research practice. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,000. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Critical Ethnography
subject: WGSS
